Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial on Hypertension Management in Aortic Coarctation Patients

Trial_Design.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence, with allocation concealment ensured by sealed envelopes.

Participants.evidence: Participants were recruited from a tertiary care center, with eligibility criteria including a confirmed diagnosis of AoC and post-repair hypertension.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomised to receive either beta-blockers, ACE inhibitors, ARBs, or CCBs.

Objective.evidence: This randomised controlled trial was conducted to evaluate the effectiveness of different antihypertensive strategies in AoC patients.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the reduction in systolic blood pressure over a 12-month period.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence, with allocation concealment ensured by sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was applied to outcome assessors.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 200 participants were randomised: 50 to each treatment group.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis was conducted on 196 participants using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The mean reduction in systolic blood pressure was greatest in the ACE inhibitor group (mean difference = 5.2 mm Hg, 95% CI 3.1 to 7.3; p = 0.01).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were reported in 3% of the ACE inhibitor group and 1% of the beta-blocker group, with mild gastrointestinal side-effects.

Trial_Registration.evidence: The trial was registered under number NCT12345678

Funding.evidence: funded by the National Heart Institute.
